data.source: 1) Unacast anonymized cell-phone mobility dataset; 2) American Community Survey (2014–2018 5-year averages); 3) MIT Election Data and Science Lab county-level 2016 vote share; 4) 2010 U.S. Census rurality classification
data.wave_or_subset: Mobility data for March 19–28, 2020, compared with matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week
data.sample_size: 3,037 U.S. counties (covering 15–17 million anonymous cell-phone users per day)
data.access_details: Unacast data provided to authors for research use; ACS, MIT Election Lab, and Census data are publicly accessible
data.notes: Mobility measure reflects change in average distance traveled; does not capture non-cell-phone users and may contain measurement error

method.description: The study linked county-level mobility changes derived from anonymized cell-phone data with socioeconomic and political characteristics to assess associations with engagement in social distancing.
steps: Acquire county-level daily mobility metrics from Unacast (average distance traveled per person).
Compute percentage-point change in mobility for March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week.
Merge mobility data with county characteristics: per-capita income, 2016 Trump vote share, demographic covariates, industry employment shares, and rurality.
Estimate bivariate ordinary least squares regressions of mobility change on each main exposure.
Estimate multivariable ordinary least squares regressions including covariates and state fixed effects.
Interpret coefficients as percentage-point change in mobility (negative values indicate greater social distancing).
method.models: Cross-sectional ordinary least squares regression with state fixed effects
method.outcome_variable: Percentage-point change in average county mobility (March 19–28 vs reference week)
method.independent_variables: Per-capita income (IQR change); Share of voters supporting Donald Trump in 2016 (IQR change)
method.control_variables: Percentage male, Black, Hispanic; age distribution; percentage with college degree; employment shares in retail, transportation, health/education/social services; rurality; state fixed effects

results.summary: After adjusting for sociodemographic factors and state fixed effects, higher county income was associated with greater social distancing, while greater support for President Trump was associated with reduced social distancing. Demographically, higher shares of racial minorities and adults without college degrees were linked to less distancing.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Change in average mobility (social distancing measure)
Change in average mobility (social distancing measure)

metadata.original_paper_title: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
